abstract: Why Caroline Kennedy’s “experience” counts.
snippet: Why Caroline Kennedy’s “experience” counts.
lead_paragraph: Outside Philadelphia, a lawyer named Whitney Hoffman is wrestling with her résumé. She barely worked a full year as a lawyer after graduating from Penn State 14 years ago, taking what she calls a “mom sabbatical” to raise her sons, who are now 10 and 13. Not that she sat around eating bonbons during those years. She researched a book on public-assembly-facility law being written by a local attorney, served on the board of a local public-­service organization, helped run the community education program for her son’s school, created a biweekly podcast on learning disabilities and organized a number of conferences, called PodCamp, to teach new-media skills. “It’s not that I don’t have experience,” she says, “but I worry that I’ll sit across the desk at an interview, and they’ll say, ‘What are you experienced for?’ ”

headline.main: In the Magazine: The Senator Track

abstract: The 250 workers who staged a sit-in at a Chicago factory last month to protest losing their jobs plan to file charges of unfair labor practices against their former employer. “The workers won justice with their pay settlement, but now they want to hold the owner accountable for closing the plant the way he did,” said Leah Fried, a field organizer for the United Electrical Workers Local 1110, referring to a deal that included 60 days of severance pay for the laid-off workers at Republic Windows and Doors. abstract: The federal Department of the Interior said it was once again lifting Endangered Species Act protection for the gray wolf in Montana and Idaho, parts of Oregon, Utah and Washington, and in the western Great Lakes. Officials said federal protection would remain in place in Wyoming. State law there, biologists say, does not assure their protection. The Bush administration has tried three times to de-list the wolf. Those decisions, however, have been reversed by judges, in response to lawsuits brought by environmentalists, who argue wolf populations are not fully recovered. The rule will be published Jan. 27 and will take effect 30 days later. JIM ROBBINS
lead_paragraph: The federal Department of the Interior said it was once again lifting Endangered Species Act protection for the gray wolf in Montana and Idaho, parts of Oregon, Utah and Washington, and in the western Great Lakes. abstract: Mayor Michael Nutter of Philadelphia said the city faces a budget deficit of $1.04 billion over the next five years and $47 million in the current year because of sharp declines in business and real estate taxes and rising pension contributions because of falling stock markets in the recession. Mr. Nutter, calling the city’s financial situation “grave and worsening,” also announced a citywide public consultation process to consider ways of closing the gap, and said all options including tax increases and layoffs were under discussion. The five-year deficit projection is in addition to a shortfall of about the same size identified in November. JON HURDLE

abstract: The intersection of Martin Luther King Day with Inauguration Eve for Barack Obama was too richly symbolic for any performer to resist. Ms. Franklin performed at “Let Freedom Ring,” named after the gospel choir that backed her up, which has performed an annual Martin Luther King Day concert since 2003. Mr. Marsalis presided over the eclectic “A Celebration of America,” telecast live on CNN, that portrayed jazz as democracy in its purest form.

abstract: Aides say that the Obama girls had a sleepover party on Tuesday night with classmates from Sidwell Friends School and were visited by a suprise guest.
snippet: Aides say that the Obama girls had a sleepover party on Tuesday night with classmates from Sidwell Friends School and were visited by a suprise guest.
lead_paragraph: The Obama girls are probably still giddy over their fun-filled first night at the White House. Aides say that Malia, 10, and Sasha, 7, had a sleepover party on Tuesday night with classmates from Sidwell Friends School, watched two movies – “High School Musical 3” and “Bolt” – and romped around the house in a scavenger hunt arranged by the White House staff. And the very best part? At the end of the hunt, the girls opened a door and found the members of their favorite musical group, the Jonas Brothers, waiting for them.

headline.main: Sasha and Malia’s Big Night

abstract: For four generations of a black family from Florida,the inauguration was a single-dose antidote to decades of racial discrimination that they had taught their children to overcome.
snippet: For four generations of a black family from Florida,the inauguration was a single-dose antidote to decades of racial discrimination that they had taught their children to overcome.
lead_paragraph: McKinley Young, a bishop in the African Methodist Episcopal Church, and his wife, Dorothy, have known disappointment. As they pastored churches in Georgia and Texas, they supported talented black politicians who were unable to win statewide office. They saw John F. Kennedy assassinated, then the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., then Robert F. Kennedy.

headline.main: Epic Campaign Divided Family, Then United It
headline.print_headline: Epic Campaign Divided Family, Then United It

Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., whom he has often referenced in his speeches, but George Washington, speaking to his bedraggled troops during the darkest days of the Revolutionary War, when, as Mr. Obama put it, “The enemy was advancing. The snow was stained with blood.”

headline.print_headline: At the Inaugural Balls, the First Couple Were the Only Celebrities Who Mattered

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — From overhead and on television, the inaugural throng on Tuesday resembled a singular human blanket sprawling over miles. Up close, what was striking were the tears, visible up and down the Mall and the parade route, dripping from the eyes of adults, children, at all points of the day.

headline.print_headline: From a Festive Crowd Come Chants and Tears

snippet: The former president returns to Texas, defending his eight years in office while vowing not to be the retiring type.
lead_paragraph: George W. Bush, now the former president, flew to Midland, Texas, after the inauguration this afternoon and told a small welcoming crowd much of what he has been saying in his farewell speeches and interviews over the last few weeks. But in light of Barack Obama’s Inaugural Address today — and the new president’s stark repudiation of what his predecessor left behind — Mr. Bush’s speech almost seemed like a rebuttal.

headline.main: Bush Again Defends His Presidency

abstract: How many commanders in chief were sworn in?

For a moment, they were like a couple of actors who missed their cues and stepped on each other’s lines.

Bush, the economy was about to spring back to life, the troops were on their way home from Iraq, there would soon be health care coverage for all, and, to quote a certain Obama foe turned Obama secretary of state-designate, “celestial choirs will be singing and everyone will know we should do the right thing and the world will be perfect.”

Cousins journeyed from the South Carolina town where the first lady’s great-great-grandfather was born into slavery, while the rabbi in the family came from the synagogue where he had been commemorating Martin Luther King’s Birthday. The president and first lady’s siblings were there, too, of course: his Indonesian-American half-sister, who brought her Chinese-Canadian husband, and her brother, a black man with a white wife.

headline.print_headline: Guided Into Tunnel, Ticket Holders Missed Swearing-In

abstract: On his second day as president, Barack Obama affirmed his support for abortion rights, as tens of thousands of anti-abortion protesters held a rally on the National Mall.
snippet: On his second day as president, Barack Obama affirmed his support for abortion rights, as tens of thousands of anti-abortion protesters held a rally on the National Mall.

Wade, and said that it “stands for a broader principle: that government should not intrude on our most private family matters.”

headline.main: On 36th Anniversary, Obama Praises Roe v. Wade Precedent

abstract: Some on the Bush team thought the inaugural speech took unnecessary shots at the departing administration.
snippet: Some on the Bush team thought the inaugural speech took unnecessary shots at the departing administration.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  On the plane, no longer Air Force One but now Special Air Mission 28000, they talked about the speech. George W. Bush, the former president, was heading home to Texas with his inner circle, having just left the Capitol, where his successor first thanked him for his service and then proceeded to discredit it.

headline.main: On Plane to Texas, Critiques of the Speech

abstract: Press Secretary Robert Gibbs begins the daily routine of jousting with the media.
snippet: Press Secretary Robert Gibbs begins the daily routine of jousting with the media.

headline.print_headline: A Diverse First Presidential Morning Prayer
